Fill in the blanks to print "Ruby is fun" to the screen.
[!raw!]
{0} "Ruby is fun"
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Hello, Ruby![/h1]

Let's create our very first Ruby program, the classic "Hello World" program.
For this, we use the built-in [b]puts [/b]method. [code format="rb" codeId="967"][b]puts [/b]"Hello World"[/code]
This code will output the text "Hello World" to the screen.
[note]All text values (strings) must be enclosed in single or double [b]quotes[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: Rearrange the code to output "My first program" to the screen.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Hello, Ruby![/h1]

Another method that can be used to display output to the screen is [b]print[/b].
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="968"][b]print[/b] "Hello World"[/code]
This code displays the same output as before, except that the [b]puts [/b] automatically adds a new line after the output, while [b]print [/b]does not.
[b]For example:[/b][code format="rb" codeId="969"]puts "Hi"
print "there"
print "Ruby"[/code]
